headline: Taco Bell parent Yum Brands misses estimates as spending slows
summary: STORY: Shares of Yum Brands fell as much as five percent Tuesday morning after the fast-food giant missed analysts’ expectations for earnings and revenue in the second quarter.Its businesses including KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell were hit by higher ingredient costs and saw weaker customer demand.Concerns over the impact of steep tariffs and economic growth have dented U.S. consumer spending on eating out, prompting Yum and competitors like McDonald's to launch budget-friendly meal deals to boost foot traffic.Taco Bell, which accounts for 38% of the company's total revenue, rolled out meal boxes ranging from $5 to $9.Still, its same-store sales growth in the U.S. which is its biggest market, slowed to 4% during the quarter from 5% a year earlier.One analyst said concerns about tariffs and a weakening job market have consumers hunting for value.The Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have also made it harder for businesses, to plan operations, disrupted supply chains, and increased costs.Yum’s incoming CEO said on a post-earnings call that the company expects inflation pressures across several key products sourced from Mexico and Canada for the rest of the year.

content.title: Taco Bell parent Yum Brands misses estimates as spending slows
content.description:
STORY: Shares of Yum Brands fell as much as five percent Tuesday morning after the fast-food giant missed analysts’ expectations for earnings and revenue in the second quarter.

Its businesses including KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell were hit by higher ingredient costs and saw weaker customer demand.

Concerns over the impact of steep tariffs and economic growth have dented U.S. consumer spending on eating out, prompting Yum and competitors like McDonald's to launch budget-friendly meal deals to boost foot traffic.

Taco Bell, which accounts for 38% of the company's total revenue, rolled out meal boxes ranging from $5 to $9.

Still, its same-store sales growth in the U.S. which is its biggest market, slowed to 4% during the quarter from 5% a year earlier.

One analyst said concerns about tariffs and a weakening job market have consumers hunting for value.

The Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have also made it harder for businesses, to plan operations, disrupted supply chains, and increased costs.

Yum’s incoming CEO said on a post-earnings call that the company expects inflation pressures across several key products sourced from Mexico and Canada for the rest of the year.
content.summary: STORY: Shares of Yum Brands fell as much as five percent Tuesday morning after the fast-food giant missed analysts’ expectations for earnings and revenue in the second quarter.Its businesses including KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell were hit by higher ingredient costs and saw weaker customer demand.Concerns over the impact of steep tariffs and economic growth have dented U.S. consumer spending on eating out, prompting Yum and competitors like McDonald's to launch budget-friendly meal deals to boost foot traffic.Taco Bell, which accounts for 38% of the company's total revenue, rolled out meal boxes ranging from $5 to $9.Still, its same-store sales growth in the U.S. which is its biggest market, slowed to 4% during the quarter from 5% a year earlier.One analyst said concerns about tariffs and a weakening job market have consumers hunting for value.The Trump administration's unpredictable trade policies have also made it harder for businesses, to plan operations, disrupted supply chains, and increased costs.Yum’s incoming CEO said on a post-earnings call that the company expects inflation pressures across several key products sourced from Mexico and Canada for the rest of the year.

headline: Yum! Brands’s (NYSE:YUM) Q2 Earnings Results: Revenue In Line With Expectations
summary: Fast-food company Yum! Brands (NYSE:YUM) met Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q2 CY2025, with sales up 9.6% year on year to $1.93 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.44 per share was 1.3% below analysts’ consensus estimates.

summary: The Louisville, Kentucky-based company said it had profit of $1.33 per share. Earnings, adjusted for non-recurring costs and pretax expenses, came to $1.44 per share. The results did not meet Wall Street expectations.

headline: Taco Bell parent Yum Brands misses estimates as spending slows, costs rise
summary: Yum Brands missed analysts' estimates for the second quarter on Tuesday, hit by higher ingredient costs and muted demand that weighed on its businesses, including Taco Bell, sending its shares down 4%. Concerns over the impact of steep tariffs and economic growth have dented U.S. consumer spending on eating out, prompting fast-food chains, including Yum Brands, McDonald's and Burger King-owner Restaurant Brands, to launch budget-friendly meal deals to boost foot traffic. Taco Bell, which accounts for 38% of the company's total revenue, rolled out meal boxes ranging from $5 to $9.

content.title: Taco Bell parent Yum Brands misses estimates as spending slows, costs rise
content.summary: Yum Brands missed analysts' estimates for the second quarter on Tuesday, hit by higher ingredient costs and muted demand that weighed on its businesses, including Taco Bell, sending its shares down 4%. Concerns over the impact of steep tariffs and economic growth have dented U.S. consumer spending on eating out, prompting fast-food chains, including Yum Brands, McDonald's and Burger King-owner Restaurant Brands, to launch budget-friendly meal deals to boost foot traffic. Taco Bell, which accounts for 38% of the company's total revenue, rolled out meal boxes ranging from $5 to $9.

headline: Wall Street ends lower as investors consider tariff impact on results, economy
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -U.S. stocks ended lower on Tuesday as investors weighed the impact of tariffs after Yum Brands and other companies cited trade duties in their results or outlooks.  In addition, a measure of activity in the U.S. services sector hit stall-speed in July, with businesses saying new import taxes are pushing costs higher.  Shares of KFC parent Yum Brands fell 5.1% after the company missed estimates for the second quarter, as steep trade duties restricted consumer spending.

content.title: Wall Street ends lower as investors consider tariff impact on results, economy
content.summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -U.S. stocks ended lower on Tuesday as investors weighed the impact of tariffs after Yum Brands and other companies cited trade duties in their results or outlooks.  In addition, a measure of activity in the U.S. services sector hit stall-speed in July, with businesses saying new import taxes are pushing costs higher.  Shares of KFC parent Yum Brands fell 5.1% after the company missed estimates for the second quarter, as steep trade duties restricted consumer spending.

headline: Disney Earnings, New Tariff Deadline, PMIs: What to Watch This Week
summary: Earnings season marches on, with results from Walt Disney and McDonald’s among this week's highlights, along with President Trump's new tariff-hike deadline for many countries. Trump also said he would name replacements this week for Federal Reserve governor Adriana Kugler and Bureau of Labor Statistics chief Erika McEntarfer.

content.title: Disney Earnings, New Tariff Deadline, PMIs: What to Watch This Week
content.summary: Earnings season marches on, with results from Walt Disney and McDonald’s among this week's highlights, along with President Trump's new tariff-hike deadline for many countries. Trump also said he would name replacements this week for Federal Reserve governor Adriana Kugler and Bureau of Labor Statistics chief Erika McEntarfer.
